note.p: "Never printed before, and now published by the authours originall copies"
First folio; includes the plays not hitherto printed, except the Wild-goose chase, which was missing, but recovered and printed in 1652. Cf. NUC pre-1956.
"The Epistle dedicatorie" is signed by John Lowin, Joseph Taylor, and eight others; "To the reader" signed by Ja. Shirley, who is usually regarded as the editor.
For complete contents of this edition, see NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Reproduction of original in Harvard University Libraries.

div.head: Scaena Prima.

sp.speaker: Virolet.
sp.l: BOy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Sir?

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: If my wife seek me, tell her that
Designes of weight, too heavy for her knowledge,
Exact my privacy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I shall, sir.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Do then,
And leave me to my selfe.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Tis a raw morning,
And would you please to interpret that for duty
Which you may construe boldnesse, I could wish
To arme your selfe against it, you would use
More of my service.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: I have heate within here,
A noble heat (good boy) to keep it off,
I shall not freeze; deliver my excuse, Enter Juliana.
And you have done your part.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: That is prevented,
My Lady follows you.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Since I must be crost then,
Let her perform that office.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I obey you. Exit.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Prethee to bed; to be thus fond's more tedious
Then if I were neglected.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Tis the fault then
Of love and duty which I would fall under,
Rather then want that care which you may challenge
As due to my obedience.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: I confesse
This tendernesse argues a loving wife,
And more deserves my hearts best thanks then anger.
Yet I must tell ye Sweet, you do exceed
In your affection, if you would ingrosse me
To your delights alone.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I am not jealous,
If my embraces have distasted you,
As I must grant you every way so worthy
That tis not in weak woman to deserve you,
Much lesse in miserable me, that want
Those graces some more fortunate are stor'd with.
Seek any whom you please, and I will study
With my best service to deserve those favours,
That shall yeeld you contentment.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: You are mistaken.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: No, I am patient sir, and so good morrow;
I will not be offensive.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Heare my reasons.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Though in your life a widdows bed receives me,
For your sake I must love it. May she prosper
That shall succeed me in it, and your ardour
Last longer to her.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: By the love I beare
First to my Countries peace, next to thy selfe
To whom compar'd, my life I rate at nothing;
Stood here a Lady that were the choyce abstract
Of all the beauties nature ever fashion'd,
Or Art gave ornament to, compar'd to thee,
Thus as thou art obedient and loving,
I should contemne and loath her.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I do believe ye.
How I am blest
In my assur'd beliefe? this is unfain'd;
And why this sadnesse then?

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Why Juliana,
Believe me, these my sad and dull retirements,
My often, nay almost continued fasts,
Sleep banisht from my eyes, all pleasures strangers,
Have neither root nor growth from any cause
That may arrive at woman. Shouldst thou be,
As chastity forbid, false to my bed,
I should lament my fortune, perhaps punish
Thy falshood, and then study to forget thee:
But that which like a never emptied spring,
Feeds high the torrent of my swelling griefe,
Is what my Countrey suffers; there's a ground
Where sorrow may be planted, and spring up,
Though yeelding rage and womanish despaire,
And yet not shame the owner.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I do believe it true,
Yet I should think my selfe a happy woman,
If in this generall and timely mourning,
I might or give to you, or else receive
A little lawfull comfort.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Thy discretion
In this may answer for me; look on Naples
The Countrey where we both were born and bred,
Naples the Paradise of Italy,
As that is of the earth; Naples, that was
The sweet retreat of all the worthiest Romans,
When they had shar'd the spoyles of the whole world;
This flourishing Kingdom, whose inhabitants
For wealth and bravery liv'd like petty Kings,
Made subject now to such a tyranny,
As that faire City that receiv'd her name
From Constantine the great, now in the power
Of barbarous Infidels, may forget her own,
To look with pity on our miseries,
So far in our calamities we transcend her.
For since this Arragonian tyrant Ferrand,
Ceaz'd on the government, there's nothing left us
That we can call our own, but our afflictions,

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: And hardly those; the Kings strange cruelty,
Equals all presidents of Tyranny.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Equall say you:
He has out gone, the worst compar'd to him;
Nor Phalaris, nor Dionisius,
Caligula, nor Nero can be mention'd;
They yet as Kings, abus'd their regall power;
This as a Marchant, all the Countries fatt,
He wholy does ingrosse unto himself;
Our Oyles he buyes at his own price, then sels them
To us, at dearer rates; our Plate and Jewels,
Under a fayn'd pretence of publique use,
He borrows; which deny'd, his Instruments force.
The rases of our horses, he takes from us;
Yet keeps them in our pastures; rapes of Matrons,
And Virgins, are too frequent; never man
Yet thank'd him for a pardon; for Religion,
It is a thing he dreames not off.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I have heard,
How true it is, I know not; that he sold
The Bishop-prick of Tarent to a Jew,
For thirteene thousand Duckets.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: I was present,
And saw the money paid: the day would leave me,
Ere I could number out his impious actions;
Or what the miserable Subject suffers;
And can you entertaine in such a time,
A thought of dalliance? teares, and sighes, and groanes,
Would better now become you.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: They indeed are,
The onely weapons, our poor Sex can use,
When we are injur'd, and they may become us;
But for men that were born free men, of Ranck;
That would be registred Fathers of their Country;
And to have on their Tombs in Golden Letters,
The noble stile of Tyrant killers, written;
To weepe like fooles, and women and not like wise men.
To practise a redresse, deserves a name,
Which fits not me to give.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Thy grave reproofe:
If what thou dost desire, were possible
To be effected? might well argue it,
As wise as loving; but if you consider,
With what strong guards, this Tyrant is defended:
Ruffins, and malecontents drawne from all quarters;
That onely know, to serve his impious will;
The Citadels built by him in the neck
Of this poor City; the invincesible strength,
Nature by Art assisted, gave this Castle;
And above all his feare; admitting no man
To see him, but unarm'd; it being death
For any to approach him with a weapon.
You must confesse, unlesse our hands were Canons,
To batter down these walls; our weake breath mines,
To blow his Forts up; or our curses lightning,
To force a passage to him; and then blast him;
Our power is like to yours, and we like you;
Weepe our misfortunes.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Walls of Brasse resist not
A noble undertaking: nor can vice,
Raise any Bulwrack, to make good the place,
Where vertue seekes to enter; then to fall
In such a brave attempt, were such an honour;
That Brutus, did he live again would envy.
Were my dead Father in you, and my Brothers;
Nay, all the Ancestors I am deriv'd from;
As you, in being what you are, are all these.
I had rather weare a mourning Garment for you,
And should be more proud of my widdow-hood;
You dying for the freedome of this Country;
Then if I were assur'd, I should injoy
A perpetuity of life and pleasure,
With you the Tyrant living.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Till this minute,
I never heard thee speake; O more then woman!
And more to be belov'd; can I finde out
A Cabinet, to lock a secret in,
Of equall trust to thee? all doubts, and feares,
That scandalize your sex, be farre from me;
Thou shalt pertake my neer and dearest councels,
And further them with thine.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I will be faithfull.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Know then this day, stand heaven propitious to us,
Our liberty begins.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: In Ferrands death?

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: 'Tis plotted love, and strongly, and beleeve it,
For nothing else could doe it; 'twas the thought,
How to proceed in this designe and end it,
That made strange my embraces.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Curs'd be she,
That's so indulgent to her own delights,
That for their satisfaction, would give
A stop to such a glorious enterprize:
For me, I would not for the world, I had been
Guilty of such a crime; goe on and prosper.
Goe on my dearest Lord, I love your Honour
Above my life; nay, yours; my Prayers go with you;
Which I will strengthen with my teares: the wrongs
Of this poor Country, edge your sword; O may it
Peirce deep into this Tyrants heart, and then
When you return bath'd in his guilty bloud,
I'le wash you cleane with fountaines of true joy.
But who are your assistants? though I am
So covetous of your glory, that I could wish
You had no sharer in it. Knock.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Be not curious.
They come, how ever you command my bosome,
To them I would not have you seene.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I am gon Sir,
Be confident; and may my resolution
Be present with you. Exit.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Such a Masculine spirit,
With more then womans vertues, were a dower
To waigh down a Kings fortune.

sp.speaker: Briss.
sp.p: Good day to you. Enter Brissonet Camillo, Ronvere.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: You are an early stirrer.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: What new face,
Bring you along?

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: If I stand doubted Sir?
As by your looks I guesse it: you much injure
A man that loves, and truly loves this Country,
With as much zeale as you doe; one that hates
The Prince by whom it suffers, and as deadly;
One that dares step as farre to gaine my freedome,
As any he that breathes; that weares a sword
As sharp as any's.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Nay, no more comparisons.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: What you but whisper, I dare speake aloud,
Stood the King by; have meanes to put in act too
What you but coldly plot; if this deserve then
Suspition in the best, the boldest, wisest?
Pursue your own intents, Il'e follow mine;
And if I not out-strip youâ€”

sp.speaker: Briss.
sp.l: Be assur'd Sir,
A conscience like this can never be allide
To treachery.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Who durst speake so much,
But one that is like us a sufferer,
And stands as we affected?

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: You are cozend
And all undone; every Intelligencer
Speakes treason with like licence; is not this
Ronvere, that hath for many yeeres been train'd
In Ferrands Schoole, a man in trust and favour,
Rewarded too and highly?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Grant all this,
The thought of what he was, being as he is now;
A man disgrac'd, and with contempt thrown off;
Will spurre him to revenge, as swift as they,
That never were in favour.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Poore and childish.

sp.speaker: Briss.
sp.l: His regiment is cast, that is most certain;
And his command in the Castle given away.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: That on my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Grosser still, what shepheard
Would yeeld the poor remainder of his flock,
To a known wolfe; though he put on the habit,
Of a most faithfull dogge, and barke like one?
As this but onely talkes.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Yes, he has meanes too.

sp.speaker: Virol.
sp.l: I know it to my griefe, weake men I know it;
To make his peace, if there were any warre
Between him and his Master, betraying
Our innocent lives.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: You are too suspitious;
And I have born too much, beyon'd my temper,
Take your own wayes, I'le leave you.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: You may stay now;
You have enough, and all indeed you fisht for;
But one word Gentlemen: have you discover'd
To him alone our plot?

sp.speaker: Briss.
sp.l: To him and others, that are at his devotion.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Worse and worse:
For were he onely conscious of our purpose,
Though with the breach of Hospitable lawes,
In my own house, Ide silence him for ever:
But what is past my help, is past my care,
I have a life to loose.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Have better hopes.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: And when you know, with what charge I have further'd
Your noble undertaking, you will sweare me
Another man; the guards I have corrupted:
And of the choyce of all our noblest youths,
Attir'd like virgins; such as Hermits would
Welcome to their sad cells, prepar'd a Maske;
As done for the Kings pleasure.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: For his safety
I rather feare; and as a pageant to
Usher our ruine.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: We as Torch-bearers
Will waite on these, but with such art and cunning;
I have convei'd sharp poniards in the Wax,
That we may passe, though search't through all his guards
Without suspition, and in all his glory,
Oppresse him, and with safety.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: 'Tis most strange.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: To be effected.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: You are doubtfull still.

sp.speaker: Briss.
sp.l: But we resolv'd to follow him, and if you
Desist now Virolet, we will say 'tis feare,
Rather then providence. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: And so we leave you, Enter Julian.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: To your wise doubts, and to my better councels;
Oh! pardon me my Lord, and trust me too;
Let me not like Cassandra prophesie truths,
And never be beleiv'd, before the mischiefe:
I have heard all; know this Ronvere a villaine,
A villaine that hath tempted me, and plotted
This for your ruine, onely to make way
To his hopes in my embraces; at more leisure
I will acquaint you, wherefore I conceil'd it
To this last minute; if you stay you are lost,
And all prevention too late. I know,
And 'tis to me known onely, a darke cave
Within this house, a part of my poor dower,
Where you may lye conceal'd, as in the center,
Till this rough blast be ore; where there is ayre,
More then to keep in life; Ferrand will find you,
So curious his feares are.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: 'Tis better fall
Then hide my head, now 'twas thine own advice,
My friends ingag'd too.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: You stand further bound,
Then to weake men that have betray'd themselves,
Or to my Councell, though then just and loyall:
Your phansie hath been good, but not your judgement,
In choyce of such to side you, wil you leape
From a steep Tower, because a desperate foole
Does it, and trusts the wind to save his hazard?
There's more expected from you; all mens eyes are fixt
On Viriolet, to help not hurt them;
Make good their hopes and ours, you have sworn often,
That you dare credit me; and allow'd me wise
Although a woman; even Kings in great Actions,
Waite opportunity and so must you Sir,
Or loose your understanding.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Thou art constant;
I am uncertain foole, a most blinde foole;
Be thou my guide.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I. I faile to direct you,
For torment or reward, when I am wretched,
May constancy forsake me.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: I've my safety.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Why are you rapt thus?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Peace, thou art a foole.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: But if I were a flatterer like your worship,
I should be wise and rich too;
There are few else that prosper, baudes excepted,
They hold an equall place there.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: A shrew'd knave;
But O the King, the happy King!

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Why happy?
In bearing a great burthen.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: What beares he,
That's born on Princes shoulders?

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: A Crownes waight,
Which sets more heavy on his head, then the ore
Slaves digge out of the Mines, of which 'tis made.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Thou worthily art his fool, to think that heavy
That carryes him in the ayre; the reverence due
To that most sacred Gold, makes him ador'd,
His Foot-steps kist, his smiles to raise a begger
To a Lords fortune; and when he but frownes,
The City quakes.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Or the poor Cuckolds in it,
Cox-combs I should say, I am of a foole.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Grown a Philosopher, to heare this parasite.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: The delicates he is serv'd with see and envy,

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: I had rather have an Onyon with a stomack,
Then these without one.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: The Celestiall Musick, still Musick.
Such as the motion of the eternall spheares
Yeelds Iove, when he drinkes Nectar.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Here's a fine knave, yet hath to many fellowes.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Then the beauties,
That with variety of choyce embraces, these passe o're.
Renew his age.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Help him to croutch rather,
And the French Cringe, they are excellent Surgeons that way.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: O Majesty! let others think of heaven,
While I contemplate thee.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: This is not Atheisme, but Court observance.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Now the God appears, usher'd with earth-quakes.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.p: Base Idolatry. Flourish Enter Ferrand, Guard, women, Servants.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: These meates are poysoned, hang
The Cookes; no note more, on
Forfeit of your fingers; doe you
Envy me a minutes slumber, what are these?

sp.speaker: 1. Gu.
sp.l: The Ladies appointed by your Majesty.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: To the purpose, for what appointed?

sp.speaker: 1. Gu.
sp.l: For your graces pleasure.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: To sucke away the little bloud is left me,
By my continuall cares; I am not apt now,
Injoy them first, taste of my dyet once;
And your turne serv'd, for fifty Crownes a peece
Their Husbands may redeem them.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: Great Sir, mercy.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I am deafe, why stare you? is what we command
To be disputed? who's this? bring you the dead
T'upbrai'd me to my face?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Hold Emperour;
Hold mightest of Kings, I am thy vassell,
Thy Foot-stool, that durst not presume to look
On thy offended face.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Castruchio rise.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Let not the lightning of thy eye consume me,
Nor heare that Musicall tongue, in dreadfull thunder,
That speakes all mercy.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Here's no flattering rogue.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Ferrand, that is the Father of his people,
The glory of mankinde.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: No more, no word more;
And while I tell my troubles to my selfe,
Be Statues without motion or voyce,
Though to be flatter'd, is an itch to greatnesse,
It now offends me.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Here's the happy man;
But speake who dares.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: When I was innocent;
I yet remember, I could eat and sleepe,
Walke unaffrighted, but now terrible to others:
My guards cannot keepe feare from me
It still pursues me; Oh! my wounded conscience,
The Bed I would rest in, is stuft with thornes;
The grounds strow'd o're with adders, and with aspicks
Where ere I set my foot, but I am in,
And what was got with cruelty, with blood,
Must be defended, though this life's a hell,
I feare a worse hereafter. ha!

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: My Lord. Enter Ronvere and guard.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Welcome Ronvere, welcome my golden plummet
With which I sound mine enemies depthes and angers,
Hast thou discover'd.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: All as you could wish Sir,
The Plot, and the contrivers; was made one
Of the conspiracie.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Is Virolet in?

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: The head of all, he onely scented me:
And from his feare, that I plaid false is fled;
The rest I have in fetters

sp.speaker: Fer
sp.l: Death and hell.
Next to my mortall foe the pyrat Sesse,
I aym'd at him; he's vertuous, and wise,
A lover of his freedome and his countries
Dangerous to such as govern by the sword,
And so to me: no tract which way he went,
No meanes to overtake him?

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Ther's some hope left;
But with a rough hand, to be seas'd upon.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: What is't?

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: If any know, or where he is,
Or which way he is fled, it is his wife;
Her with his Father I have apprehended,
And brought among the rest.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: 'Twas wisely order'd,
Go fetch them in, and let my executioners Exit Ronvere.
Appeare in horrour with the racke.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: I take it signeur, this is no time for you to flatter,
Or me to foole in.

sp.speaker: Cast
sp.l: Thou art wise in this, let's off, it is unsafe to be nere Jove,
When he begins to thunder.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Good morality. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I that have peirc'd into the hearts of men;
Forc'd them to lay open with my lookes,
Secrets whose least discovery was death,
Will rend for what concernes my life, the fortresse,
Of a weake womans faith. Enter Ronvere, guard, Executioners with a Rack, Camillo, Brissonet Pandulfo, Juliana.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: What ere we suffer,
The waight, that loads a Traytors
Heart sit ever, heavy on thine.

sp.speaker: Briss
sp.l: As we are caught by thee,
Fall thou by others.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Pish poor fools, your curses will
Never reach me.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Now by my Virolets life;
Father, this is a glorious stage of murther.
Here are five properties too, and such spectators,
As will expect good action, to the life;
Let us performe our parts, and we shall live,
When these are rotten, would we might begin once;
Are you the Master of the company?
Troth you are tedious now.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: She does deride me.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Thee and thy Power, if one poor syllable
Could win me, an assurance of thy favour,
I would not speake it, I desire to be
The great example of thy cruelty,
To whet which one, know Ferrand, I alone
Can make discovery, where my Virolet is,
Whose life, I know thou aym'st at, but if tortures
Compell me to't, may hope of heaven forsake me;
I dare thy worst.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Are we contemn'd.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Thou art,
Thou and thy Ministers, my life is thine;
But in the death, the Victory shall be mine.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: We have such a Mistresse here to teach us courage,
That cowards might learn from her.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: You are slow; put on the rack.
Begin the Scene thou miserable foole
For so I'le make thee.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: 'Tis not in thy reach;
I am happy in my sufferings, thou most wretched.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: So brave! Ile tame you yet, pluck hard villains;
Is she insensible? no sigh nor groan? or is she dead?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: No tyrant, though I suffer
More then a woman, beyond flesh and blood;
Tis in a cause so honourable, that I scorn
With any sign that may expresse a sorrow
To shew I do repent.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Confesse yet,
And thou shal be safe.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Tis wrapt up in my soule,
From whence thou canst not force it.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I will be
Ten daies a killing thee.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Be twenty thousand,
My glory lives the longer.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Tis a miracle,
She tires th'executioners,
And me.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Unloose her, I am conquer'd, I must take
Some other way; reach her my chaire, in honour
Of her invincible fortitude.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Will you not
Dispatch the rest?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: When I seem mercifull,
Assure thy selfe Ronvere, I am most cruell.
Thou wonder of thy sex, and of this Nation,
That hast chang'd my severity to mercy,
Not to thy selfe alone, but to thy people,
In which I do include these men, my enemies:
Unbind them.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: This is strange.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: For your intent
Against my life, which you dare not deny,
I onely aske one service.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Above hope.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: There rides a Pyrate neer, the Duke of Sesse,
My enemy and this Countries, that in bonds
Holds my deere friend Ascanio: free this friend,
Or bring the Pyrats head; besides your pardon,
And honour of the action, your reward
Is forty thousand Ducates. And because
I know that Virolet is as bold as wise,
Be he your Generall, as pledge of your faith,
That you wil undertake it: let this old man,
And this most constant Matron stay with me;
Of whom, as of my selfe, I wil be carefull;
She shall direct you where her husband is.
Make choice of any ship you think most useful.
They are rig'd for you.

div.stage: Exeunt Guard, with Juliana and Pand.

sp.speaker: Bris.
sp.l: We with joy accept it.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: And wil proclaim King Ferrant mercifull.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: The mysterie of this, my Lord? or are you
Chang'd in your nature?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Ile make thee private to it.
The lives of these weake men, and desperate woman,
Would no way have secur'd me, had I took them;
Tis Virolet I aime at; he has power,
And knows to hurt. If they encounter Sesse,
And he prove conquerour, I am assur'd
They'l finde no mercy: if that they prove victors,
I shall recover with my friend; his head
I most desire of all men.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Now I have it.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Ile make thee understand the drift of all.
So we stand sure, thus much for those that fall. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.l: Ley here before the wind; up with her Canvase
And let her work, the wind begins to whistle;
Clap all her streamers on, and let her dance,
As if she were the Minion of the Ocean.
Let her bestride the billows till they rore,
And curle their wanton heads. Ho, below there:
Ho, ho, within.
Ley her North-east, and thrust her missen out,
The day grows faire and cleare, and the wind Courts us.
O for a lusty saile now, to give chase to.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: A stubborn Barke, that wo'd but bear up to us,
And change a broadside bravely.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.l: Where's the Duke?

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: I have not seen him stir to day.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.l: O Gunner,
What bravery dwels in his age, and what valour?
And to his friends, what gentlenesse and bounty?
How long have we been inhabitants at Sea here?

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: Some fourteen yeers.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.l: By fourteen lives I swear then,
This Element never nourisht such a Pirate;
So great, so fearlesse, and so fortunate,
So patient in his want, in Act so valiant.
How many saile of wel man'd ships before us,
As the Bonuto does the flying fish,
Have we pursued and scowerd, that to outstrip us,
They have been fain to hang their very shirts on?
What Gallies have we bang'd, and sunke, and taken;
Whose onely fraughts were fire, and stern defiance?
And nothing spoke but Bullet in all these.
How like old Neptune have I seen our Generall
Standing ith' Poope, and tossing his steel Trident,
Commanding both the Sea and Winds to serve him?

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: His daughter too, which is the honour, Boteswain,
Of all her sex; that Martiall mayd.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.l: A brave wench.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: How oftentimes, a fight being new begun,
Has she leap'd down, and took my Linstock from me,
And crying, now fly right, fir'd all my chasers?
Then like the Image of the warlike Goddesse,
Her Target brac'd upon her arme, her Sword drawn,
And anger in her eyes, leap'd up again,
And bravely hal'd the Barke. I have wondred Botswain,
That in a body made so delicate,
So soft for sweet embraces, so much fire,
And manly soule, not starting at a danger.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.l: Her Noble father got her in his fury,
And so she proves a souldier.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: This to I wonder at,
Taking so many strangers as he does,
He uses them with that respect and coolnesse,
Not making prize, but onely borrowing
What may supply his want: nor that for nothing;
But renders back what they may stand in need of,
And then parts lovingly: Where, if he take
His Countreyman, that should be neerest to him,
And stand most free from danger, he sure pays for't:
He drownes or hangs the men, ransacks the Barke,
Then gives her up a Bonfire to his fortune.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.l: The wrongs he has receiv'd from that dull Countrey,
That's all I know has purchas'd all his cruelty.
We fare the better; cheerly, cheerly boys,
The ship runs merrily; my Captain's melancholy,
And nothing cures that in him but a Sea-fight:
I hope to meet a saile boy, and a right one.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: That's my hope too; I am ready for the pastime.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.l: I'th mean time let's bestow a song upon him,
To shake him from his dumps, and bid good day to him.
Ho, in the hold. Enter a Boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Here, here.

sp.speaker: Botes.
sp.l: To th' main top boy.
And thou kenst a ship that dares defie us,
Here's Gold.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I am gon. Exit Boy.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.l: Come sirs, a queint Levet. Trump. a levet.
To waken our brave Generall. Then to our labour.

div.stage: Enter Duke of Sesse above and his daughter Martia like an Amazon.

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: I thank you loving mates; I thank you all.
There's to prolong your mirth, & good morrow to you.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: Take this from me, you'r honest valiant friends;
And such we must make much of. Not a sayle stirring?

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: Not any within ken yet.

sp.speaker: Botes.
sp.l: Without doubt Lady,
The wind standing so faire and full upon us,
We shal have sport anon. But noble Generall,
Why are you still so sad? you take our edge off;
You make us dull, and spirit-lesse.

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: Ile tell ye,
Because I wil provoke you to be fortunate;
For when you know my cause, twill double arme you.
This woman never knew it yet; my daughter,
Some discontents she has.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: Pray sir go forward.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: These fourteen yeeres, I have stoed it here at Sea,
Where the most curious thought could never find it.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.l: Call up the Master, and all the Mates.

div.stage: Enter below the Master and Saylers.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Good morrow.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Good morrow to our Generall, good one,
And to that Noble Lady all good wishes.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: I thank you Master.

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: Mark me, thus it is then;
Which I did never think to have discovered,
Till full revenge had wooed me; but to satisfie
My faithfull friends, thus I cast off my burden.
In that short time I was a Courtier,
And followed that most hated of all Princes,
Ferrant the full example of all mischiefes,
Compel'd to follow to my soule a stranger,
It was my chance one day to play at Chesse
For some few Crowns, with a mynion of this Kings,
A mean poor man, that onely serv'd his pleasures;
Removing of a Rook, we grew to words;
From this to hotter anger: to be short,
I got a blow.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: How, how my Noble father?

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: A blow my girle, which I had soon repayd,
And sunk the slave for ever, had not odds
Thrust in betwixt us. I went away disgrac'dâ€”

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: For honours sake not so sir.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: For that time, wench;
But calld upon him, like a Gentleman,
By many private friends; knockt at his valour,
Courted his honour hourely to repaire me;
And tho he were a thing my thoughts made sleight on,
And onely worth the fury of my footman,
Still I pursued him Nobly.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: Did he escape you?
My old brave father, could you sit down so coldly?

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Have patience, and know all. Pursued him fairly,
Till I was laught at, scornd, my wrongs made maygames.
By him unjustly wrong'd, should be all justice,
The slave protected; yet at length I found him,
Found him, when he suppos'd all had been buried;
And what I had received durst not be questioned;
And then he fell, under my Sword he fell,
For ever sunk; his poore life, like the ayre,
Blown in an empty bubble, burst, and left him,
No Noble wind of memory to raise him.
But then began my misery, I fled;
The Kings frowns following, and my friends dispaires;
No hand that durst relieve: my Countrey fearfull,
Basely and weakly fearfull of a tyrant;
Which made his bad wil worse, stood still and wondred,
Their vertues bedrid in e'm; then my girle,
A little one, I snatch'd thee from thy nurse,
The modell of thy fathers miseries:
And some small wealth was fit for present carriage,
And got to Seal; where I profest my anger,
And wil do, whilst that base ungratefull Countrey,
And that bad King, have blood or means to quench me.
Now ye know all.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: We know all, and admire all;
Go on and do all still, and still be fortunate.

sp.speaker: Daught.
sp.l: Had you done lesse, or lost this Noble anger,
You had been worthy then mens empty pities,
And not their wonders. Go on, and use your justice;
And use it still with that fell violence
It first appeared to you; if you go lesse,
Or take a doting mercy to protection,
The honour of a father I disclaim in you,
Call back all duty, and will be prowder of
The infamous and base name of a whore,
Then daughter to a great Duke and a coward.

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: Mine own sweet Martia, no; thou knowst my nature,
It cannot, must not be.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: I hope it shal not.
But why sir, do you keep alive still young Ascanio,
Prince of Rossana, King Ferrants most belov'd one,
You took two moneths agoe?
Why is not he flung overboord, or hang'd?

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Ile tell thee girle:
It were a mercy in my nature now,
So soon to break the bed of his afflictions;
I am not so far reconcil'd yet to him
To let him die, that were a benefit.
Besides, I keep him as a bayt and dyet,
To draw on more, and neerer to the King,
I look each hour to heare of his Armados,
And a hot welcome they shall have.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: But hark you?
If you were overswayed with oddesâ€”

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: I find you:
I would not yield; no girle, no hope of yeelding,
Nor fling my self one houre into their mercies,
And give the tyrant hope to gain his Kingdom.
No, I can sink wench, and make shift to die;
A thousand doores are open, I shal hit one.
I am no niggard of my life, so it goe Nobly:
All waies are equall and all houres; I care not.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: Now you speak like my father.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Noble General,
If by our means they inherit ought but bangs,
The mercy of the main yard light upon us.
No, we can sinke too sir, and sinke low enough,
To pose their cruelties, to follow us:
And he that thinks of life, if the world go that way,
A thousand cowards suck his bones.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: Let the worst come,
I can unbreech a Canon, and without much help
Turn her into the Keele; and when she has split it,
Every man knows his way, his own prayers,
And so good night I think.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: We have liv'd all with you, Boy a top.
And will die with you Generall.

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: I thank you Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Boy above.
sp.l: A Sayle, a Sayle.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: A cheerfull sound.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: A Sayle.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.l: Of whence? of whence boy?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: A lusty sayle.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: Look right, and look again.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: She plows the Sea before her,
And fomes i'th mouth.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.l: Of whence?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I ken not yet sir.

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: O may she prove of Naples.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Prove the Divell,
We'l spit out fire as thick as she.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Hoy.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Brave boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Of Naples Naples, I think of Naples, Master,
Me thinks I see the Armes.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Up, up another,
And give more certain signes. Exit Saylor.

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: All to your businesse,
And stand but right and trueâ–ª

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.l: Hang him that halts now.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Sh'as us in chase.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: We'l spare her our main top-saile,
He shall not look us long, we are no starters,
Down with the fore-saile too, we'l spoom before her.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Gunner, good noble Gunner, for my honour
Load me but these two Minions in the chape there;
And load 'em right, that they may bid faire welcome,
And be thine eye and level as thy heart it.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: Madam, Ile scratch 'em out, Ile pisse 'em out else.

sp.speaker: Sayl. above.
sp.l: Ho.

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: Of whence now?

sp.speaker: Sayl.
sp.l: Of Naples, Naples, Naples.
I see her top flag how she quarters Naples.
I heare her Trumpets.

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: Down, she's welcome to us. Exit Mast. Bots. Gun. Sayl.
Every man to his charge, man her i'th bowe wel.
And place your rakers right, daughter be sparing.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: I sweare Ile be above sir, in the thickest,
And where most danger is, Ile seek for honour.
They have begun, harke how their Trumpets call us.
Hark how the wide mouth'd Cannons sing amongst us.
Heark how they saile; out of our shels for shame sir.

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: Now fortune and my cause.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Be bold and conquer. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: They'l board us once again, they'r tuffe & valiant.

sp.speaker: Botes.
sp.l: Twice we have blown 'em into th'ayre like feathers.
And made 'em dance.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Good boys, fight bravely, manly. Enter Gunner.
They come on yet; clap in her stern, & yoke 'em.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: You shall not need, I have provision for 'em;
Let 'em boord once again, the next is ours.
Stand bravely to your Pikes, away, be valiant.
I have a second course of service for 'em,
Shall make the bowels of their Barke ake, hoy
The Duke fights like a Dragon. Who dares be idle. Exit. Charge, Trumpets, pieces goe off.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Down with 'em, stow 'em in.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.l: Cut their throats, tis brotherhood to fling em into the Sea.
The Duke is hurt, so is his lovely daughter Martia.
We have the day yet. Enter Gunner.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.p: Pox fire'em, they have smok'd us, never such plumbs yet flew.

sp.speaker: Bots.
sp.l: They have rent the ship, & bor'd a hundred holes,
She swims still lustily.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: She made a brave fight, and he shall be cur'd,
And make a braver yet.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.p: Bring us some Cans up, I am hot as fire. Enter Boy with 3 Cans.

sp.speaker: Botes.
sp.l: I am sure I am none o'th coolest.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: My Cannons rung like Bels. Here's to my Mistris.
The dainty Sweet brasse Minion, split their fore-mast,
She never failed.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Ye did all well, and truly, like faithfull honest men.

sp.speaker: Botes.
sp.p: But is she rich Master? Trumpet flourish.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Rich for my Captains purpose howsoever,
And we are his.- How bravely now he shows,
Heated in blood and anger? how do you sir?
Not wounded mortally I hope?

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: No Master, but onely weare the livery of fury.
I am hurt, and deep.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: My Mistris too?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: A scratch man,
My needle would ha done as much good sir,
Be provident and carefull.

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: Prethee peace girle,
This wound is not the first blood I have blusht in,
Ye fought all like tall men, my thanks among ye,
That speaks not what my purse means, but my tongue, souldiers.
Now sir, to you that sought me out, that found me,
That found me what I am, the Tyrants Tyrant;
You that were imp'd the weak arme to his folly,
You are welcome to your death.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: I do expect it,
And therefore need no complement, but waite it.

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: Thou bor'st the face once of a Noble Gentleman,
Rankt in the first file of the vertuous,
By every hopefull spirit, shewed and pointed,
Thy Countries love; one that advanc'd her honour,
Not taynted with the base and servile uses
The Tyrant ties mens soules too. Tell me Virolet,
If shame have not forsook thee, with thy credit.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: No more of these Racks; what I am I am.
I hope not to go free with poore confessions;
Nor if I show ill, will I seem a monster,
By making my mind prisoner; do your worst.
When I came out to deale with you, I cast it,
Onely those base inflictions fit for slaves,
Because I am a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: Thou art none.
Thou wast while thou stoodst good, th'art now a villain
And agent for the divell.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: That tongue lies.
Give me my Sword again, and stand all arm'd;
He prove it on ye all, I am a Gentleman,
A man as faire in honour; rate your prisoners;
How poore and like a Pedagogue it shews?
How far from Noblenesse? tis fair, you may kil's;
But to defame your victory with foule language.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Go, fling him overboord; Ile teach you sirra.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: You cannot teach me to die. I could kill you now
With patience, in despising all your cruelties.
And make you choke with anger.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Away I say.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Stay sir, h'as given you such bold language,
I am not reconcil'd to him yet, and therefore
He shall not have his wish observ'd so neerly,
To die when he please; I beseech you stay sir.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Do with him what thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Carry him to th'Bilboes,
And clap him fast there, with the Prince.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: Do Lady,
For any death you give, I am bound to blesse you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Now to your Cabin, sir; pray lean upon me,
And take your rest, the Surgeons waite all for you.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Thou makest me blush to see thee bear thy fortuns;
Why, sure I have no hurt, I have not fought sure?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: You bleed apace, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Ye grow cold too.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: I must be ruld, no leaning,
My deepest wounds scorn Crutches.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: A brave Generall. Flor. Trumpets, Cornets.

sp.speaker: 1 Sayl.
sp.l: Will they not moore her?

sp.speaker: 2 Sayl.
sp.l: Not till we come to the Fort,
This is too weak a place for our defences,
The Carpenters are hard at worke; she swims well,
And may hold out another fight. The ship we took
Burns there to give us light.

sp.speaker: 1 Sayl.
sp.l: She made a brave fight.

sp.speaker: 2 Sayl.
sp.l: She put us all in feare.

sp.speaker: 1 Sayl.
sp.l: Beshrew my heart did she.
Her men are gone to Candy, they are pepper'd,
All but this prisoner.

sp.speaker: 2 Sayl.
sp.l: Sure he's a brave fellow.

sp.speaker: 1 Say.
sp.l: A stubborn knave, but we have pul'd his bravery.
sp.stage: He discovers Virolet and Ascanio in the Bilboes.
sp.l: Look how he looks now: come let's go serve his dyet,
Which is but bread and water.

sp.speaker: 2 Sayl.
sp.l: He'l grow fat on't. Exeunt Saylors.

sp.speaker: Ascan.
sp.l: I must confesse I have endured much misery,
even almost to the ruine of my spirit,
But ten times more grows my affliction,
To finde my friend here.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: Had we serv'd our Countrey,
Or honesties, as we have serv'd our follies,
We had not been here now?

sp.speaker: Ascan.
sp.l: Tis to true Virolet.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: And yet my end in ventring for your safety,
Pointed at more then Ferrants will, a base one;
Some service for mine own, some for my Nation,
Some for my friend; but I am rightly payd,
That durst adventure such a Noble office,
From the most treacherous command of mischiefe;
You know him now?

sp.speaker: Ascan.
sp.l: And when I neerer knew him,
Then when I waited, Heaven be witnesse with me,
(And if I lie my miseries still load me)
With what teares I have woed him, with what prayers,
What weight of reasons I have layd, what dangers;
Then, when the peoples curses flew like storms;
And every tongue was whetted to defame him,
To leave his doubts, his tyrannies, his slaughters,
His fell oppressions. I know I was hated too.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: And all mankind that knew him: these confessions
Do no good to the world, to Heaven they may.
Let's study to die well, we have liv'd like coxcombs.

sp.speaker: Ascan.
sp.l: That my mis-fortune, should lose you too.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: Yes;
And not onely me, but many more, and better:
For my life, tis not this; or might I save yours,
And some brave friends I have engag'd, let me go;
It were the meritorious death I wish for,
But we must hang or drown like whelps.

sp.speaker: Ascan.
sp.l: No remedy.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: On my part I expect none. I know the man,
And know he has been netled to the quick too,
I know his nature.

sp.speaker: Ascan.
sp.l: A most cruell nature.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: His wrongs have bred him up. I cannot blame him.

sp.speaker: Ascan.
sp.l: He has a daughter too, the greatest scorner,
And most insulter upon misery.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: For those, they are toyes to laugh at, not to lead men:
A womans mirth or anger, like a meteor
Glides and is gone, and leaves no crack behind it;
Our miseries would seem like masters to us,
And shake our manly spirits into feavors,
If we respected those; the more they glory,
And raise insulting Trophies on our ruines;
The more our vertues shine in patience.
Sweet Prince, the name of death was never terrible
To him that knew to live; nor the loud torrent
Of all afflictions, singing as they swim,
A gall of heart, but to a guilty conscience:
Whilst we stand faire, but by a two-edg'd storm,
We find untimely fals, like early Roses;
But to the earth, we beare our native sweetnesse.

sp.speaker: Ascan.
sp.l: Good sir go on.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: When we are little children,
And cry and fret for every toy comes crosse us;
How sweetly do we shew, when sleep steales on us?
When we grow great, but our affections greater,
And struggle with this stubborn twin, born with us;
And tug and pull, yet still we finde a Giant:
Had we not then the priviledge to sleep,
Our everlasting sleep? he would make us ideots;
The memory and monuments of good men
Are more then lives, and tho their Tombs want tongues,
Yet have they eyes, that daily sweat their losses;
And such a teare from stone, no time can value.
To die both young and good, are natures curses,
As the world says; ask truth, they are bountious blessings:
For then we reach at Heaven, in our full vertues,
And fix our selves new Stars, crown'd with our goodnes.

sp.speaker: Asc.
sp.l: You have double arm'd me. Srange Musick within, Hoboys.
Hark, what noyse is this?
What horrid noyse is the Sea pleas'd to sing,
A hideous Dirg to our deliverance?

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.p: Stand fast now. Within strange cries, horrid noyse, Trumpets.

sp.speaker: Asc.
sp.l: I am fixt.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: We feare ye not. Enter Martia
Let death appear in all shapes, we smile on him.

sp.speaker: Asc.
sp.l: The Lady now.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: The face oth' Maske is alter'd.

sp.speaker: Asc.
sp.l: What will she doe?

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: Do what she can, I care not.

sp.speaker: Asc.
sp.l: She looks on you sir.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: Rather she looks through me,
But yet she stirs me not.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Poore wretched slaves,
Why do you live? or if ye hope for mercy,
Why do not you houle out, and fill the hold
With lamentations, cries, and base submissions,
Worthy our scorn?

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: Madam, you are mistaken;
We are no slaves to you, but to blind fortune;
And if she had her eyes, and durst be certain,
Certain our friend, I would not bow unto her;
I would not cry, nor aske so base a mercy:
If you see any thing, in our appearance,
Worthy your sexes softnes and your own glory?
Do it for that; and let that good reward it:
We cannot beg.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Ile make you beg, and bow too.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: Madam for what?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: For life; and when you hope it,
Then will I laugh and triumph on your basenesse.

sp.speaker: Asc.
sp.l: Madam tis true, there may be such a favour,
And we may aske it too; aske it with honour;
And thanke you for that favour, nobly thank you,
Tho it be death; but when we beg a base life,
And beg it of your scornâ€”

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: Y'are couzened woman,
Your handsomnesse may do much, but not this way;
But for your glorious hateâ€”

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Are ye so stubborn?
Death, I will make you bow.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: It must be in your bed then;
There you may worke me to humility.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Why, I can kill thee.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: If you do it handsomely;
It may be I can thank you, elseâ€”

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: So glorious?

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.l: Her cruelty now workes.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Yet woot thou?

sp.speaker: Virt.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Wilt thou for life sake?

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: No, I know your subtilty.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: For honour sake?

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: I will not be a Pageant,
My mind was ever firm, and so Ile lose it.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Ile starve thee to it.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: Ile starve my selfe, and crosse it.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Ile lay thee on such miseriesâ€”

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: Ile weare 'em,
And with that wantonnesse, you do your Bracelets.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Ile be a moneth a killing thee.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: Poore Lady,
Ile be a moneth a dying then: what's that?
There's many a Callenture outdoes your cruelty.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: How might I do, in killing of his body,
To save his Noble mind? Who waites there?

div.stage: Enter a Saylor with a rich Cap and Mantle.

sp.speaker: Sayl.
sp.l: Maddam.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Unbolt this man, and leave those things behind you,
And so away. Now put 'em on. Unbolt him. Exit Sailor.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: To what end?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: To my end, to my will.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: I thank you.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: Nay, now you thank me, Ile do more. Ile tell ye,
I am a servant to your curtesie,
And so far will be wooed: but if this triumph
Be onely aym'd, to make your mischiefe glorious;
Lady, y'ave put a richer shroud upon me,
Which my strong mind shall suffer in.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Come hither,
And all thy bravery put into thy carriage,
For I admire thee.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: Whither will this woman?

sp.speaker: Asc.
sp.l: Take heed my friend.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Look as thou scorndst my cruelty:
I know thou doest.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: I never fear'd, nor flatter'd.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: No if thou hadst, thou hadst died, & I had gloried.
I suffer now, and thou which art my prisoner,
Hast Nobly won the free power to despise me.
I love thee, and admire thee for thy Noblenesse;
And for thy manly sufferance, am thy servant.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Good Lady, mock me not.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: By Heaven I love thee;
And by the soule of love, am one piece with thee.
Thy mind, thy mind; thy brave, thy manly mind:
That like a Rock stands all the storms of fortune,
And beats 'em roaring back they cannot reach thee:
That lovely mind I dote on, not the body;
That mind has rob'd me of my liberty:
That mind has darken'd all my bravery,
And into poor despis'd things, turn'd my angers.
Receive me to your love sir, and instruct me;
Receive me to your bed, and marry me:
Ile wait upon you, blesse the houre I knew you.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: Is this a new way?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: If you doubt my faith,
First take your liberty; Ile make it perfect,
Or any thing within my power.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: I love you;
But how to recompence your love with marriage?
Alas, I have a wife.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Dearer then I am?
That will adventure so much for your safety?
Forget her fathers wrongs, quit her own honour,
Pull on her for a strangers sake, all curses?

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Shall this Prince have his freedom too?
Else all I love is gone, all my friends perish.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: He shall.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: What shall I do?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: If thou despise my curtesie,
When I am dead, for griefe I am forsaken,
And no soft hand left to asswage your sorrows;
Too late, but too true, curse your own cruelties.

sp.speaker: Ascan.
sp.l: Be wise; if she be true, no thred is left else,
To guide us from this laborinth of mischiefe;
Nor no way for our friends.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: Thus then, I take you:
I bind ye to my life, my love.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: I take you,
And with the like bond tye my heart your servant;
W'are now almost at Harbour, within this houre,
In the dead watch, Ile have the long boat ready;
And when I give the word, be sure you enter,
Ile see ye furnisht both immediately,
And like your selfe; some trusty man shall wait you,
The watch Ile make mine own; onely my love
Requires a stronger vow, which Ile administer
Before we go.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: Ile take it to confirm you.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Go in, there are the Keys, unlock his fetters,
And arme ye Nobly both; Ile be with you presently,
And so this loving kisse.

sp.speaker: Ascan
sp.l: Be constant Lady. Exeunt omnes.

div.stage: Enter the Duke of Sesse by Torchlight, Master and Surgeon, with him.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.l: You grow so angry sir, your wound goes backward.

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: I am angry at the time, at none of you,
That sends but one poor subject for revenge;
I would have all the Court, and all the villany,
Was ever practiz'd under that foule Ferrand
Tyrant, and all to quench my wrath.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Be patient,
Your grace may find occasion every houre,
For certaine they will seeke you, to satisfy,
And to the full, your anger.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Death, they dare not:
They know that I command death, feed his hunger,
And when I let him looseâ€”

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: You'l never heale sir,
If these extreames dwell in you, you are old,
And burn your spirits out with this wild angers.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Thou liest, I am not old, I am as lusty
And full of manly heat as them, or thou art.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: No more of that.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: And dare seek out a danger;
And hold him at the swords point, when thou tremblest
And creepest into thy box of salves to save thee.
O Master, I have had a dreadfull dream to night!
Me-thought the ship was all on fire, and my lov'd Daughter,
To save her life, leapt into th' Sea; where suddainly
A stranger snatch'd her up, and swom away with her.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.p: 'Twas but the heate o'th fight sir. Boateswain within & Sailor.

sp.speaker: Botes.
sp.l: Look out, what's that?

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.l: The long bote as I live.

sp.speaker: Bote.
sp.p: Ho, there, ith long Bote. She claps on all her Oares.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: What noise is that? Hoy.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: I hear sirâ€” Exit Master.

sp.speaker: Boats.
sp.l: The devill or his dam; haile her agen boyes.

sp.speaker: Ssail.
sp.l: The long boate, ho, the long boate.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Why, the long boate?
Where is the long Boate?

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.l: She is stolne off. En. Master.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Who stole her?
O my prophetique soule!

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Your daughter's gone sir;
The prisoners, and six Saylors, rogues.

sp.speaker: Ses
sp.l: Mischief, six thousand plagues sale with 'em;
They'r in her yet, make out.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: We have ne'r a Boate. En. Gunner.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: Who knew of this trick?

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Weigh Anchors and away.

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.l: We ha' no winde sir,
They'l beate us with their Oares.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Then sinke 'em Gunner,
O sink 'em, sink 'em, sink 'em, claw 'em Gunner;
As ever thou hast lov'd me.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: I'le do reason,
But I'le be hangd before I hurt the Lady. Exit Gun.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.p: Who knew of this? Trump. a peece or two go off.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: We stand all clear.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: What divel
Put this base trick into her tayle? my daughter,
And run away with rogues! I hope she's sunk, A peece or two.
Or torne to pieces with the shot; rots find her,
The leprosy of whore, stick ever to her, En. Gunner.
O she has ruind my revenge.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: She is gone sir,
I cannot reach her with my shot.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Rise winds, blow till you burst the aire,
Blow till ye burst the aire, and swell the Seas,
That they may sink the starres, O dance her, dance her;
Shes impudently wanton, dance her, dance her,
Mount her upon your surges, coole her, coole her
She runs hot like a whore, coole her, coole her;
O now a shot to sink her; come, cut Cables;
I will away, and where she sets her foote
Although it be in Ferrants court, Ile follow her,
And such a fathers vengeance shall she sufferâ€”
Dare any man stand by me?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: All, all.

sp.speaker: Boats.
sp.l: All sir.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: And the same cup you taste.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Cut Cables then;
For I shall never sleep, nor know what peace is,
Till I have pluckt her heart out;

sp.speaker: All within.
sp.l: O maine there. Exeunt.

div.head: Scoena prima.
div.stage: Enter Ferrant, Ronvere, Castruchio, Villo, and Guard.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: You are too gentle sir. Florish cornets.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: You are too carelesse:
The creatures I have made, no way regard me:
Why should I give you names, titles of honour
Rob families, to fill your private houses
For your advancement, draw all curses on me,
Wake tedious winter nights, to make them happy
That for me break no slumber?

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: What we can,
We dare doe

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Why is your Soveraignes life then
(In which you live, and in whose fall your honours,
Your wealth, your pomp, your pride and all must suffer)
No better guarded? O my cruell Stars,
That marke me out a King, raising me on
This pinnacle of greatnesse, only to be
The neerer blasting!

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: What think you now Castruchio?
Is not this a merry life?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Still thou art couzend;
It is a glorious royall discontentment;
How bravely it becomes him!

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: To be made
The common butt, for every slave to shoot at;
No peace, no rest I take, but their alarams
Beat at my heart: why do I live, or seek then,
To adde a day more to these glorious troubles?
Or to what end when all I can arrive at,
Is but the summing up of feares and sorrowes,
What power has my command, when from my bosom
Ascanio my most dear, and lov'd Ascanio,
Was snatch'd, spite of my wil, spite of my succor,
And by mine own proud slave reteind most miserable?
And still that villains lives to nip my pleasures,
It being not within my power to reach him.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Time may restore all this; and would you hear
Whose counsell never faild you.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Tell me no more,
I faint beneath the burthen of my cares,
And yeild my selfe most wretched.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: On my Knees
I beg it might sir, vouchsafe me hearing.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Speak, speak, and I thus low, such is my fortune,
Will hear what thou canst say.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Look but on this,
Has not a man that has but means to keep
A Hawk, a Grayhound, and a hunting Nag,
More pleasure then this King?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: A dull foole still,
Make me a King, and let me scratch with care,
And see who'l have the better; give me rule,
Command, obedience, pleasure of a King,
And let the devil rore; The greatest corrosive
A King can have, is of more pretious tickling,
And handled to the height more dear delight,
Then other mens whole lives, let 'em be safe too.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Think of the mutinous people.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Hang the people,
Give me the pleasure, let me do all, awe all,
Enjoy their wives and states at my discretion,
And peg 'em when I please, let the slaves mumble.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: But say they should be vex'd, and rise against thee?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Let 'em rise, let 'em rise: give me the bridle here,
And see if they can crack my girths: ah Villio,
Under the Sun, ther's nothing so voluptuous
As riding of this monster, till he founder.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Who's that so lowd?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: I am dumb: is not this rare?
Kings looks make Pythagoreans; is not this
A happinesse Villio?

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Yes, to put to silence
A fawning sycophant.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Thou speak'st truth in all,
And mercy is a vice, when there needs rigour,
Which I with all severity will practise;
And since as subjects they pay not obedience.
They shall be forc'd as slaves: I wil remove
Their meanes to hurt, and with the means, my fears:
Goe you the fatall executioners
Of my commands, and in our name proclame,
That from this houre I do forbid all meetings,
All private conferences in the City:
To feast a neighbour shall be death; to talke,
As they meete in the streetes, to hold discourse,
By writing, nay by signes; see this perform'd,
And I wil call your cruelty, to those
That dare repine at this, to me true service.

sp.speaker: 1 Gard.
sp.l: This makes for us.

sp.speaker: 2. Gard.
sp.l: I now we have imployments,
If we grow not rich 'twere fit we should be beggers.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Ronvere. Exit Guard.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Thou enemy to Majesty?
What think'st thou of a Kingdome?

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: As of a man
That hath power to doe ill.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Of a thing rather
That does divide an Empire with the Gods;
Observe but with how little breath he shakes
A populous City, which would stand unmov'd
Against a whirlewind.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Then you make him more
Then him that rules the winds.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: For me I doe professe it,
Were I offerd to be any thing on Earth,
I would be mighty Ferrant.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Ha? who names me?
Deliver thy thoughts slave, thy thoughts, and truly,
Or be no more.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: They rather will deserve.
Your favour then your fury; I admire,
(As who does not, that is a loyall subject?)
Your wisdom, power, your perfect happinesse,
The most blest of mankind.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Didst thou but feele
The weighty sorrowes, that sit on a Crown,
Tho thou shouldst find one in the streets Castruchio,
Thou wouldst not think it worth the taking up;
But since thou art enamour'd of my fortune,
Thou shalt ere long taste of it.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: But one day,
And then let me expire.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Goe to my wardrop,
And of the richest things I wear, cull out,
What thou thinkst fit: do you attend him sirra.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: I warrant you, I shall be at his elbow,
The foole wil never leave him. Exit Cast. Villio.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Made for ever. A shout within.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: What shout is that? draw up Guards.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Those rather En. Virolet, Ascanio, and a servant.
Speake joy then danger.
Bring her to my house,
I would not have her seen here.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: My Ascanio!
The most desir'd of all the men, let me die
In these embraces; how wert thou redeem'd?

sp.speaker: Asc.
sp.l: Sir, this is my preserver.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: At more leasure,
I will inquire the manner, and the meanes,
I cannot spare so much time now from my
More strickt embraces: Virolet, welcome too,
This service weighes down your entended treason;
You long have bin mine enemy, learn now
To be my friend and loyall, I aske no more,
And live as free as Ferrant; let him have
The forty thousand crowns I gladly promis'd,
For my Ascanios freedom, and deliver
His Father, and his wife to him in safety,
Something hath passed which I am sorry for,
But 'twill not now be help'd; come my Ascanio,
And reap the harvest of my winter travels. Florish Cornets. Exit Fer. Ascanio.
My best Ascanio, my most lov'd Ascanio.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: My Lord, all former passages forgot,
I am become a suitor.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: To me Virolet?

sp.speaker: Virol.
sp.l: To you, yet will not beg the courtesie,
But largely pay you for it.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: To the purpose.

sp.speaker: Virol.
sp.l: The forty thousand crownes the King hath given me,
I will bestow on you, if by your meanes
I may have liberty for a divorce
Between me and my wife.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Your Juliana?
That for you hath indur'd so much, so nobly?

sp.speaker: Virol.
sp.l: The more my sorrow; but it must be so.

sp.speaker: Ron
sp.l: I will not hinder it: without a bribe,
For mine own ends, I would have further'd this.
I will use all my power.

sp.speaker: Virol.
sp.l: 'Tis all I aske:
Oh my curs'd fate, that ever man should hate
Himselfe for being belov'd, or be compeld
To cast away a Jewell, Kings would buy,
Tho with the losse of Crown and Monarchy! Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: How do I look?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: You are so strangely alterd,
We scarce can know you, so young againe, and utterly
From that you were, figure, or any favourâ–ª
Your friends cannnot discern you.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: I have none,
None but my faire revenge, and let that know meâ–ª
You are finely alterd too.

sp.speaker: Boats.
sp.l: To please your humour,
But we may passe without disguise, our living
Was never in their element.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: This Jew sure,
That alter'd you, is a made knave.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: O! a most excellent fellow.

sp.speaker: Gun,
sp.l: How he has mew'd your head, has rub'd the show off,
And run your beard into a peak of twenty!

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.l: Stopt all the crannies in your face.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Most rarely.

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.l: And now you look as plump, your eyes as sparkling,
As if you were to leap into a Ladies saddle.
Has he not set your nose awry?

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: The better.

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.l: I think it be the better, but tis awry sure;
North and by East. I ther's the point it stands in;
Now halfe a point to th'Southward.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: I could laugh,
But that my businesse requires no mirth now;
Thou art a merry fellow.

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.l: I would the Jew sir,
Could steer my head right, for I have such a swimming in't,
Ever since I went to Sea first.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Take wine and purg it.

sp.speaker: Boate.
sp.l: I have had a thousand pils of Sack, a thousand;
A thousand pottle pils.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: Take more.

sp.speaker: Boate.
sp.l: Good Doctor, En. Citizens, severally.
Your patient is easily perswaded.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: The next faire open weather
Me thinks this Jew,
If he were truly known to founder'd Courtiers,
And decaied Ladies, that have lost their fleeces
On every bush, he might pick a pretty living.

sp.speaker: Boate.
sp.l: The best of all our gallants, now be glad of him;
For if you marke their marches, they are tender,
Soft, soft, and tender; then but observe their bodies,
And you shall find 'em cemented by a Surgeon,
Or some Physitian for a year or two,
And then to th'tub again, for a new pickle.
This Jew might live a Gentile here. En. 2. Citizens at both dores, saluting afar off.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: What are these?
Stand close and marke?

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.l: These are no men, th'are motions.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: What sad and ruthfull faces!

sp.speaker: Boate.
sp.l: How they duck!
This sencelesse, silent courtesie me thinks,
Shewes like two Turkes, saluting one another,
Upon two French porters backs.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: They are my Countrymen,
And this, some forc'd infliction from the tyrant;
What are you? why is this? why move thus silent
As if you were wandring shadowes? why so sad?
Your tongues seald up; are yee of severall Countries?
You understand not one another?

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: That's an English man,
He lookes as though he had lost his dog.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Your habits
Shew ye all Neapolitanes, and your faces
Deliver you oppressed things: speak boldly:
Do you groan, and labor under this stiffe yoak?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: They shake their heads and weep.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: O misery!
Give plenteous sorrow, and no tongues to shew 'em!
This is a studied cruelty.

sp.speaker: 1. Citi.
sp.l: Be gon sir,
It seemes you are a stranger and your selfe;

sp.speaker: 2. Citi.
sp.l: You wonder here at us, as much we wonder
To hear you speak so openly, and boldly,
The Kings command being publisht to the contrary;
Tis death here, above two to talk together;
And that must be but common salutation neither,
Short and so part.

sp.speaker: Boate.
sp.l: How should a man buy mustard,
If he be forc'd to stay the making of it?
Cleare all the streetes before the King:

sp.speaker: 1. Cit.
sp.l: Get off Sir,
And shift as we must do. Exeunt Citizens

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: I'le see his glory.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.p: Stand fast now and like men, Flourish colours.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Begin the game sir, En. Castrucrio like the King, in the midst of a gard. Villio.
And pluck me down, the Row
Of houses there.
They hide the view oth' hill; and sink those merchants,
Their ships are foule and stinke.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: This is a sweete youth.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: All that are taken in assemblies,
Their houses and their wives, their wealthes are fore it,
Their lives at your devotion. Villaines, Knaves,
I'le make you bow & shake, I'le make you kneele Rogues.
How brave tis to be a King?

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: Here's fine tumbling.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: No man shall sit i'th' temple neer another.

sp.speaker: Boate.
sp.l: Nor lie with his own wife.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: All upon paine
Of present death, forget to write.

sp.speaker: Boate.
sp.l: That's excellent,
Carriers and foot-Posts, wil be arrant Rebels.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: No Character, or stamp that may deliver
This mans intention, to that man i'th' Country.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: Nay, an you cut off, after my hearty commendations
Your friend and Oliver. No more.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: No man smile,
And wear a face of mirth; that fellowes comming,
And hides a double heart, he's your prize, smoke him.

div.stage: Enter Virolet, Ronvero, Ascanio, and Martia, Passing over.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: What base abuse is this? Ha? tis her face sure,
My prisoners with her too? by heaven wild whore
Now is my time.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Do what you will.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Stay hold yet,
My Country shall be serv'd first, let her go,
Wee'l have an hour for her to make her tremble.
Now shew your selves, and blesse you with your valors.

sp.speaker: Guard
sp.p: Here's a whole plump of Rogues. Virolet and they off againe.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Now for your Country.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Away with 'em and hang 'em; no, no mercy,
I say no mercy.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Be it so upon 'em.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: Treason, treason, treason.

sp.speaker: Boate.
sp.l: Cut the slaves to giggets.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: Down with the bul-beefes.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Hold, hold, I command youâ€” look here

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: A miserable thing. I am no King sir.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Sirra, your fooles face has preserv'd your life.
Wear no more Kings coates, you have scap'd a scouring.

sp.speaker: Boate.
sp.l: I'st not the King.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: No, tis a prating Rascall,
The puppy makes him mirth.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Yes sir, I am a puppy.

sp.speaker: Boate.
sp.l: I beseech you let me hang him,
I'le do't in my belt straight.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: As you are honorable,
It is enough you may hang me.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: I'le hang a squib at's taile
That shall blow both his buttocks, like a petar.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Do any thing.
But do not kill me Gentlemen. Enter Citizen.

sp.speaker: Boate.
sp.l: Lets flea him, and have him flye blowen.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.l: Away, and save your lives.
The King himselfe is conning on: if you stay,
You are lost for ever; let not so much noblenesse
Willfully perish.

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: How neer?

sp.speaker: 2. Citiz.
sp.p: He's here behind you. Ex. Sess. Boatsw. Saylers, Citizens.

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: We thank you. vanish.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Double the Guards and take in men that dare,
These slaves are frighted; where are the proud Rebels,
To what protection fled, what villain leads 'em?
Under our nose disturb our rest?

sp.speaker: Ronver.
sp.l: We shall heare,
For such a search I have sent, to hunt the Traytors.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Yet better men I say, we stand too open:
How now Castruchio? how do you like our glory?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: I must confesse, 'twas somewhat more then my match Sir;
This open glory agrees not with my body,
But if it were ith' Castle, or some strength,
Where I might have my swing.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: You have been swing'd brother;
How these delights have tickled you? you itch yet;
Will you walke out again in pomp?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Good Foole.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: These rogues must be rebuked, they are too sawcy,
These peremptory Knaves. Will you walk out Sir,
And take the remnant of your Coronation?
The people stay to see it.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Do not vex him;
Ha's griefe enough in's bones; you shall to th' Citadell,
And like my selfe command, there use your pleasure,
But take heed to your person.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: The more danger;
Still the more honour Brother.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: If I reign not then,
And like a King, and thou shalt know it fool,
And thou shalt feel it foole.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Fooles still are freemen,
I'le sue for a protection, till thy reigne's out.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: The people have abus'd the liberty
I late allowed, I now proclaime it straighter,
No men shall walk together, nor salute;
For they that doe shall dye.

sp.speaker: Ronver.
sp.l: You hit the right Sir;
That liberty cut off, you are free from practise.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Renew my guards.

sp.speaker: Ronver.
sp.l: I shall.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: And keep strict watches;
One houre of joy I aske.

sp.speaker: Ronver.
sp.l: You shall have many. Exeunt. Flor. Cor.

div.stage: Pandulfo, and Iuliana, led by two of the guard, as not yet fully recover'd.

sp.speaker: 1. Guard.
sp.l: You are now at liberty, in your own house Lady,
And here our charge takes end.

sp.speaker: Pandul.
sp.l: 'Tis now a Custome.
We must even wooe those men deserve worst of us,
And so we thanke your labours; there's to drinke,
For that, and mischiefe are your occupations;
And to meane well to no man, you Chief'st harvests.

sp.speaker: 2. Gard.
sp.l: You give liberally; we hope Sir, er't be long,
To be oftner acquainted with your bounty,
And so we leave you.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Doe, for I dote not on ye;

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: But where's my Husband? what should I do here?
Or what share have I in this joy, cal'd liberty,
Without his company? Why did you flatter me,
And tell me he was return'd, his service honour'd?

sp.speaker: 1. Gard.
sp.l: He is so, and stands high in the Kings favour,
His friends redeemd, and his own liberty,
From which yours is deriv'd, confirm'd; his service,
To his own wish rewarded: so fare-well Lady. Ex. Guard.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Go persecute the good, and hunt ye hell-hounds;
Ye Leeches of the time, suck till ye burst slaves;
How does my girle?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Weake yet, but full of comfort;

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Sit down, and take some rest;

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: My heart's whole Father;
That joyes, and leaps, to heare my Virolet,
My Deer, my life, has conquer'd his afflictions.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Those rude hands, and that bloody will that did this,
That durst upon thy tender body Print
These Characters of cruelty; heare me heaven.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: O Sir be sparing.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: I'le speake it, tho I burst;
And tho the ayre had eares, and serv'd the Tyrant,
Out it should goe: O heare me thou great Justice;
The miseries, that waite upon their mischiefs,
Let them be numberlesse, and no eye pitty
Them when their soules are loaden, and in labour,
And wounded through, and through, with guilt & horror,
As mine is now with griefe; let men laugh at 'em
Then, when their monstrous sins, like earth-quaks, shake 'em;
And those eyes, that forgot heaven would look upward,
The bloody 'larms, of the conscience beating,
Let mercy flye, and day strook into darknesse,
Leave their blind soules, to hunt out their own horrors.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Enough, enough, we must forget deare Father;
For then we are glorious formes of heaven; and live,
When we can suffer, and as soon forgive.
But where's my Lord? me thinkes I have seen this house,
And have been in't before.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Thine own house jewell.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Mine, without him? or his, without my company?
I thinke it cannot be; it was not wont Father.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Some businesse with the King (let it be good heaven)
Reteines him sure. Enter Boy.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: It must be good and noble,
For all men that he treats with taste of vertue;
His words and actions are his own; and Honour's
Not bought, nor compel'd from him.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Here's the Boy.
He can confirme us more, how sad the child looks?
Come hither Lucio; how, and where's thy Master?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Speak gentle Boy.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Is he return'd in safety?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: If not, and that thou knowest is miserable,
Our hopes and happinesse declin'd for ever;
Study a sorrow, excellent as thy Master,
Then if thou canst live, leave us.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: Noble Madam,
My Lord is safe return'd, safe to his friends, and fortune,
Safe to his Country, entertain'd with honour,
Is here within the house.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Doe not mock me.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: But such a melancholy hangs on his mind,
And in his eyes inhabit such sad shadowes;
But what the cause isâ€”

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Goe tell him we are here Boy,
There must be no cause now.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Hast thou forgot me?

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: No, noblest Lady.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Tell him I am here,
Tell him his wife is here, sound my name to him,
And thou shalt see him start; speake Iuliana,
And like the Sunne that labors through a tempest,
How suddainly he will disperse his sadnesse?

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Goe I command thee instantly,
And charge him on his duty.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: On his Love Boy:
I would faine goe to him.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Away, away, you are foolish.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Beare all my service sweet Boy.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Art thou here still?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: And tell him what thou wilt that shall become thee.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: ith' house; and know we are here. Ex. Boy.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: No, no, he did not;
I warrant you he did not: could you think
His Love had lesse then wings, had he but seen me;
His strong affection any thing but fire
Consuming all weak lets, and rubs before it,
Till he had met my flame, and made one body?
If ever heavens high blessings met in one man,
And there erected to their holy uses,
A sacred mind, fit for their services,
Built all of polisht honour, 'twas in this man:
Misdoubt him not.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: I know he's truly noble;
But why this sadnesse, when the generall cause
Requires a Jubile of joy?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I know not. Enter Virolet, and Boy.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Pray heaven you find it not.

sp.speaker: Jul
sp.l: I hope I shall not:
O here he comes, and with him all my happinesse;
He staies and thinks, we may be too unmannerly;
Pray give him leave. they stand off.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: I doe not like this sadnesse.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: O hard condition of my misery!
Unheard of plagues! when to behold that woman,
That chaste and vertuous woman, that preserv'd me,
That pious wife, wedded to my afflictions,
Must be more terrible then all my dangers.
O fortune, thou hast rob'd men of my making,
The noble building of a man, demolisht,
And flung me headlong, on a sin so base
Man and mankind contemn; even beasts abhor it,
A sin more dull then drinke, a shame beyond it;
So foule, and farre from faith; I dare not name it,
But it will cry it self out, loud ingratitude.
Your blessing Sir.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: You have it in abundance;
So is our joy, to see you safe.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: My Deere one;

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: H'as not forgot me yet: O take me to you Sir.

sp.speaker: Vir.
